Erasmus's first letter to Pio in Rome, dated 10 October 1525, was the overture of the long lasting polemics with the Italian prince. Pio spent several months on an answering letter, dated Rome 15 May 1526, many times as long as the one he had received from Erasmus. When Pio had this letter printed four years later, in Paris in 1529, the scene was moved from the Italian to the French capital and the controversy became fully public. Continued until 1532, it would number five more documents of increasing size and grimness.ยนโท Although Aleander was not mentioned by name in Erasmus's contributions to the controversy, he haunts the back- ground throughout the polemics. In his Responsio to Pio's printed letter, Erasmus informed his addressee that in 1520 he had already heard about the hostility of a Roman โCaesaris oratorโ' whom he now understood to be Pio. His informant for this had been the former Papal legate at Worms, that is Aleander, โyour most devoted compliceโ'' โalter tibi iuratissimus sodalis.''
